 Oooh, that's one better than Archie could do. Let's take a look at the relevant bits, then.
 
 Piltdown man (CW). This response states three things. (paraphrased, response)
 
 1. "Piltdown shows that hoaxes can persist for a long time". Well, yes. However, that isn't grounds for assuming that all of the multitude of evidence pointing towards evolution is a hoax - just that all things should be looked at critically. As Piltdown Man was eventually uncovered, this shows that 'evolutionists' are (eventually) critical with their analysis.
 
 2. "The evolution-based mindset of everyone who looked at Piltdown meant that the hoax wasn't discovered until it had been published". This is an unprovable claim. It is also contrary to the fact that Piltdown was not universally accepted within the scientific community (a TO claim which CW did not refute).
 
 3. "Creationists didn't plan the pro-creation fakes". Again, unprovable. However, more importantly, this response reeks of hypocrisy. Some creationists seized on 'their' hoaxes to further the creationism viewpoint, just as some scientists seized on Piltdown Man to prove their theory. CW is trying to have one and deny the other, which isn't logically consistent.
 
 Nebraska Man. This response states just the one thing: "Nebraska Man illustrates the danger of basing discoveries on such scant evidence." However, the TO response itself says that such a 'discovery' was not made - the whole thing was labelled as speculation in the first place and then retracted entirely and publicly on the finding of more evidence.
 
 Orce Man: Based on the response here, I don't think this is a particularly valid claim for the creationists to make. A piece of bone was found, which was originally identified (by an non-ascertainable number of people) as coming from the oldest European human found. Accordingly, a meeting was called. However, the sample was further analysed (evidence of critical analysis) and the meeting cancelled when it's authenticity was called into question.
 
 This just demonstrates the successful scientific method at work, and further refutes CW point 2 from Piltdown Man that 'the evolutionist viewpoint warps everybody's perceptions'.
 
 Lucy.
 Creationwiki's response: "Ooops, yeah, that was our bad"
 
 Archeoraptor. The response here was "All Chinese fossils should be treated as fakes until otherwise proven". However, this isn't a valid assertion to make - it's akin to saying that 'because this man is guilty of murder, all other men are not presumed guilty until proven innocent'.
 
 So... out of all of those, the only real theme that remains is 'scientists should be more critical of their findings'. Given the few number of 'hoaxes' compared to the vast majority of non-hoax fossils, etc that have been found and which also support evolution,I'd say that they are being pretty critical anyway - and also that your case from this thread is reduced to squat.
